content: By Larry Kaplow | NEWSWEEK “It's too late to fix Iraq before the pullout date. All U.S. troops can do now is keep trying to slow the killing and get out. They call it 'Iraqi good enough.'” “Until now it was impossible to predict with confidence what the end of the war would look like in Iraq. But a clear picture could be emerging here in Mahmudiyah. The outcome is hardly what the occupation's supporters wanted, but it's too late for anyone to do much about that, under the deadlines set by the new U.S.-Iraqi security agreement. By the middle of this year, American combat forces must complete their official withdrawal from population centers. Security duties will be left to Iraqi forces, although U.S. military trainers and advisers will remain. As of Dec. 31, 2011, three years from now, all U.S. troops are to be out of the country. Meanwhile they still have their hands full in the northern city of Mosul, where insurgents and jihadists have dug in for another showdown, and Iraqis are bracing for more violence in the run-up to elections at the end of this month.” “The situation is summed up in a phrase you hear among American combat troops and trainers: "Iraqi good enough." The term expresses their resignation—realism, they'd call it—about the limits of what America can accomplish in Iraq. They say it when an Iraqi Army unit has no choice but to buy fuel for its Humvees on the private market because Iraq's military-supply system is so corrupt and inefficient. Or when the persistent shortage of capable leaders forces Iraqi battalions to function with only half the number of officers they require. Or when Iraqi soldiers fall apart in a senior officer's absence because that's the way it goes in a top-down society. "The concept has spread to American Embassy staffers, who invoke it when speaking of the near-impossible task of reforming the decrepit old welfare-state economy. "Good enough" may not live up to Americans' hopes for Iraq, but at this point it describes the place we're likely to leave behind in 2011—if things stay on track.” “Success is not no violence.” Commander in Chief, George W. Bush – May 2, 2007. Mission accomplished. But what was the point?

My opinion....I'm fine with pulling out some of the troops as long as it is done so while relying heavily on the advice of the Commanders onscene, not the advice of some goofball in a suit(s) sitting in D.C.. My greatest fear is that the troops left behind will be attacked once the majority leaves. Will they have enough numbers to defend themselves? Don Proud father of a US Marine

content: quote: Originally posted by L0A1: Mission accomplished. But what was the point? Sorry, but this op is FOS. Iraq has FREE Elections, FREE of tyranny, we have won the war. For people to say otherwise is disingenous. This guy has an obvious hatred for anything Bush, so the BDS continues.[/QUOTE] Disingenuous is to say we won any thing more than the defeat of Saddam and his army in May 2003. Even President Bush never claimed victory in Iraq. There were many claims of success in decreasing the violence and providing enough security to allow for elections – but no announcement of victory. The official position of the Bush Administration in the last few months of their term was that the security situation was “fragile and reversible.” The “surge” strategy did not defeat any enemy of the United States. What it did was to turn around the mistakes made by the CinC and his crew after the initial invasion. Now President Bush signed an agreement to have all troops out by 12-31-11, but al Qaeda still exists in Iraq and no one who speaks honestly thinks that the Iraqi security forces can finish off al Qaeda. If the security situation remains as it is today, three years from now, what was accomplished besides the disposal of one pizz ant dictator?

title: Iraq – good enough

content: There are issues, but as an advisor over there the "good enough" means just that. Some advisors want to have an Iraqi unit that looks and functions just like an American unit. However, they have their own command and control structure and their own way of doing things. If you go in as an advisor to an Iraqi unit and expect the S1 through 6 to function the same as a US battalion you are in for a long tour. If you go in and coach them on the right things to do you will see results, but it is a long process. New MiTTs are often frustrated by the perceived lack of cooperation, but it take time. I had huge successes in Iraq, but I took every opportunity to be around my counterparts. It took several months but once they trusted me it was very rewarding. The good MiTT teams know this and act accordingly, some do not and expect their counterparts to listen to them like they have actual command authority, which they do not. There are issues. I have dealt with not having fuel to put in T-72s to even be able to train new drivers. I have dealt with shortages of parts. I have wrestled with massive amount of paperwork needed in the Iraqi supply chain to be able to draw training ammunition. The Iraqi supply system is complex, and it is very hard to get basic items. It is not perfect and it never will be, but it has gotten much better. When I first started as an advisor the unit I was with had enough fuel to run generators for 4 to 6 hours a day. When I left we could run 12-14 hours a day. Early on the tanks and APCs at the Iraqi Armor School were functional but fuel was very limited. When I left we had enough fuel to run them through exercises and we were able to conduct the first live fire exercise with the main guns since the T-72s had been purchased almost 3 years earlier.

content: quote: Originally posted by nspreitler: There are issues, but as an advisor over there the "good enough" means just that. Some advisors want to have an Iraqi unit that looks and functions just like an American unit. However, they have their own command and control structure and their own way of doing things. If you go in as an advisor to an Iraqi unit and expect the S1 through 6 to function the same as a US battalion you are in for a long tour. If you go in and coach them on the right things to do you will see results, but it is a long process. New MiTTs are often frustrated by the perceived lack of cooperation, but it take time. I had huge successes in Iraq, but I took every opportunity to be around my counterparts. It took several months but once they trusted me it was very rewarding. The good MiTT teams know this and act accordingly, some do not and expect their counterparts to listen to them like they have actual command authority, which they do not. There are issues. I have dealt with not having fuel to put in T-72s to even be able to train new drivers. I have dealt with shortages of parts. I have wrestled with massive amount of paperwork needed in the Iraqi supply chain to be able to draw training ammunition. The Iraqi supply system is complex, and it is very hard to get basic items. It is not perfect and it never will be, but it has gotten much better. When I first started as an advisor the unit I was with had enough fuel to run generators for 4 to 6 hours a day. When I left we could run 12-14 hours a day. Early on the tanks and APCs at the Iraqi Armor School were functional but fuel was very limited. When I left we had enough fuel to run them through exercises and we were able to conduct the first live fire exercise with the main guns since the T-72s had been purchased almost 3 years earlier. There is no doubt that you and those Americans who served in Iraq have done an outstanding job. No battles lost, every mission accomplished. Questioning the validity of the war in Iraq is not reflection on those who served there. We know that politics and policy has nothing to do with why Americans serve in the military. It is more the big picture that I was referring to when I asked: besides defeating Saddam in Iraq, what was the point if we are to leave the country with a corrupt government and America’s number one enemy operating there?

I have dealt with not having fuel to put in T-72s to even be able to train new drivers. I have dealt with shortages of parts. I have wrestled with massive amount of paperwork needed in the Iraqi supply chain to be able to draw training ammunition. The Iraqi supply system is complex, and it is very hard to get basic items. content: quote: The “surge” strategy did not defeat any enemy of the United States. What it did was to turn around the mistakes made by the CinC and his crew after the initial invasion. You can believe your own reality if you want I guess. Far be it from anyone to listen to those of us who were there in 2006-2007 and witnessed it happen. Maybe you'll believe these guys: Abu-Tariq, al-Qaeda leader “There were almost 600 fighters in our sector before the tribes changed course 360 degrees . . . Many of our fighters quit and some of them joined the deserters . . . As a result of that the number of fighters dropped down to 20 or less.” “We were mistreated, cheated and betrayed by some of our brothers who used to be part of the Jihadi movement, therefore we must not have mercy on those traitors until they come back to the right side or get eliminated completely.” Unnamed emir, Anbar province “The Islamic State of Iraq [al-Qaeda] is faced with an extraordinary crisis, especially in al-Anbar province. Al-Qaeda’s expulsion from Anbar created weakness and psychological defeat. This also created panic, fear and the unwillingness to fight. “The morale of the fighters went down and they wanted to be transferred to administrative positions rather than be fighters. There was a total collapse in the security structure of the organisation.”
quote: The “surge” strategy did not defeat any enemy of the United States. What it did was to turn around the mistakes made by the CinC and his crew after the initial invasion.

Iraq has FREE Elections, FREE of tyranny, we have won the war. For people to say otherwise is disingenous. This guy has an obvious hatred for anything Bush, so the BDS continues.
reply: Disingenuous is to say we won any thing more than the defeat of Saddam and his army in May 2003. Even President Bush never claimed victory in Iraq. There were many claims of success in decreasing the violence and providing enough security to allow for elections – but no announcement of victory. The official position of the Bush Administration in the last few months of their term was that the security situation was “fragile and reversible.” The “surge” strategy did not defeat any enemy of the United States. What it did was to turn around the mistakes made by the CinC and his crew after the initial invasion. Now President Bush signed an agreement to have all troops out by 12-31-11, but al Qaeda still exists in Iraq and no one who speaks honestly thinks that the Iraqi security forces can finish off al Qaeda. If the security situation remains as it is today, three years from now, what was accomplished besides the disposal of one pizz ant dictator?[/QUOTE] al Qaeda still exists in Iraq and no one who speaks honestly thinks that the Iraqi security forces can finish off al Qaeda. NO, NO, NO, NOT TRUE!!!! You obviously don't listen to Bill over at FOX, or you would know better. quote: O'REILLY: Look, by all accounts, the Bush administration defeated Al Qaeda, all right? Al Qaeda was marginalized, been downgraded as a threat to the world. So we won the terror war. We won the war in Iraq, at great cost no doubt. No doubt. But we won. >>>http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,507385,00.html It's over, over there. Bring em home... War on terror won as well, no need to send anymore troops to A-stan either.
